Sir Winston Churchill

British politician, army officer and writer.

The main facts of Sir Winston Churchill's life on the timeline:

  • 1874 - Born in Blenheim, Oxfordshire.
  • 1894 - Graduates from officer training school at Royal Military College in Sandhurst, Berkshire.
  • 1895 - Churchill's father, Lord Randolph dies at the age of 45.
  • 1899 - Churchill runs for Parliament as part of the Conservative Party. He loses the election but impresses many with his campaigning skills.
  • 1900 - The year after losing his bid for Parliament, Churchill wins a seat in the British House of Commons.
  • 1904 - After a fall-out within his party, Churchill switches to the Liberal Party.
  • 1908 - Churchill marries Clementine Hozier in a packed St. Margaret's Church at Westminster Abbey. They will have five children together.
  • 1940 - During World War II, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain resigns and Churchill becomes prime minister. He refuses to negotiate an armistice with Germany and two months later, the Germans begin to bomb London in the Battle of Britain.
  • 1941 - Churchill arrives in Washington, D.C. to discuss war strategy with President Franklin Roosevelt. He and Roosevelt have developed a close friendship that will last until Roosevelt's death.
  • 1943 - Receives a diploma of honor at a ceremony at Harvard University.
  • 1945 - Churchill joins Roosevelt and Soviet Premiere Joseph Stalin at the Yalta Conference to discuss the organization of Europe after World War II. The controversial decision to allow Germany to be divided into communist and non-communist contributes to the tension of the Cold War. Churchill is defeated by Clement Atlee in the general elections for the prime minister. Most voters believe Atlee was better equipped to lead the country in social reform and housing crisis.
  • 1946 - Churchill says an "iron curtain" has fallen over Europe, refers to Stalin's plan to spread communism across Europe and the term "iron curtain" becomes part of the political vocabulary.
  • 1951 - Churchill is elected prime minister for the second time, defeating Clement Atlee, as a member of the Conservative Party. He focuses on domestic affairs while maintaining a close working relationship with the United States government.
  • 1953 - Author of 40 books, Churchill wins the Nobel Prize for literature for his entire body of work and particularly for the six-volume set of World War II.
  • 1955 - With difficulty speaking and walking, Churchill removes the prime minister of England. He suffers another minor stroke the following year.
  • 1965 - After another stroke, Churchill dies at his home in London at age 90. His funeral is the largest state funeral in world history, attended by representatives of 112 countries.

    • "Time and money are largely interchangeable terms."

    - Sir Winston Churchill
    Read more about this amazing personality on his Wikipedia entry.
